perturbation.original_text: Subcontractor agrees to indemnify and defend EDGE from and against any lien claims and to discharge any lien or furnish an indemnity bond equal to the lien amount (or any greater amount required by law) within ten (10) days notice from EDGE of the presence of any lien.
perturbation.changed_text: Subcontractor agrees to indemnify and defend EDGE from and against any lien claims and to discharge any lien or furnish an indemnity bond equal to the lien amount (or any greater amount required by law) within two (2) days notice from EDGE of the presence of any lien.
perturbation.explanation: Texas law (and most states) provides more than two days to respond to a lien notice. Reducing the response time to two days creates a contradiction and places an unreasonable burden on the subcontractor, potentially violating due process.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Texas Property Code, Chapter 53, Mechanic's Liens

perturbation.original_text: After fifteen (15) days prior written notice to Subcontractor to cure, or additional time as may be reasonably required by EDGE to cure the event of default, EDGE may terminate this Agreement, or any one or more awarded Purchase Orders and take control of the Work for such terminated Purchase Orders, including any or all materials for the Work, and may proceed with the completion of the Work as contemplated by this Agreement by whatever method deemed expedient by EDGE upon the occurrence of any of the following events, which shall be deemed events of a default by Subcontractor hereunder:
perturbation.changed_text: After five (5) days prior written notice to Subcontractor to cure, or additional time as may be reasonably required by EDGE to cure the event of default, EDGE may terminate this Agreement, or any one or more awarded Purchase Orders and take control of the Work for such terminated Purchase Orders, including any or all materials for the Work, and may proceed with the completion of the Work as contemplated by this Agreement by whatever method deemed expedient by EDGE upon the occurrence of any of the following events, which shall be deemed events of a default by Subcontractor hereunder:
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period to five days may conflict with Texas law regarding reasonable notice and opportunity to cure, especially for complex construction or service contracts. Many disputes require more than five days to resolve, making this provision potentially unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Texas Business and Commerce Code, and common law principles of reasonable notice

perturbation.original_text: Such notice shall be deemed to have been given or made when actually received or seventy-two (72) hours after being sent as specified above, whichever occurs first.
perturbation.changed_text: Such notice shall be deemed to have been given or made when sent as specified above.
perturbation.explanation: Texas law, particularly in legal contexts, typically requires a reasonable period for notice to be considered effective, accounting for potential delays in delivery. Eliminating the 'actually received or seventy-two (72) hours' clause and stating that notice is effective immediately upon sending is legally problematic. Certified or registered mail has a tracking period, and the law does not allow the elimination of time to receive. This creates a conflict with standard legal practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Texas Rules of Civil Procedure, and common law principles of due process
